Target Usage:
There are several major applications of this concept in the control of electricity grids, including:

  1. Develop flexible and rapid responses to grid emergencies while minimising customer impact;
  2. Balancing volatile renewable supply and EV demand, to minimise CO2 emissions;
  3. Manipulate inter-regional power flows to avoid the high costs of future power link upgrades;
  4. Provide energy markets with an additional control capability;
  5. Offer individual customers and service providers more information and control of their electric vehicle charging applications.
Name: Charging Optimisation System (COS)

Documentation.Glossary:
Term Definition
API Application Programming Interface
COS Charging Optimisation System
DSO Distribution System Operator
EV Electric Vehicles
EVSE Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment
GE Generic Enabler
TSO Transmission System Operator
Documentation.Details:
The COS API which is up and available to use, allows a user to view or control an EVSE or access various aggregated trial-site load information e.g. aggregated EV load, renewable energy supply, etc.
This API would open possibilities of integration of EV control into different end user applications (mobile/web applications) for smart home management, energy management, etc.
The API follows the rules of a common RESTful approach:

  1. Rely on HTTP/RESTful services (wherever possible) in order to address the most broad community of application developers with the popular technology
  2. Expose WP5 Stream I EV charging infrastructure and trial results
  3. Expose the COS interface allowing the system to be accessible for external applications.

From a developers point of view the API it is documented in swagger and available at the API website: https://finesce.tssg.org/documentation/index.html

API Control functions

The base url for all requests is https://finesce.tssg.org/api/v2 , and any requests using http will be redirected to https, of note a self-signed cert is used for SSL.

￼￼WP5 have implemented the following HTTP commands being used to manipulate the data controlled by the FINESCE system.
  1. HTTP GET commands used to retrieve information from the database
  2. HTTP PUT commands used to update individual record in the database
  3. HTTP POST to add new records to the database
  4. HTTP DELETE to remove records from the database

The following endpoints are currently implemented in the external API system on collection resources. All calls require an auth_token to be sent with the request (This excludes the tokens endpoint). NOTE: the parameter for sending the authorisation token is "auth_token".

  1. Miscellaneous
  2. Generationplants
  3. Regionalaggevseenergies
  4. Timeslots
  5. Evevseconnections
  6. Chargingmodes
  7. Electricvehicles
  8. Estimatedsocs
  9. Regions
  10. Generationtypes
  11. Regionalenergies
  12. Evses
  13. Evevseconnectionstates
  14. Evtypes
  15. Stateofcharges
Documentation.Preface:
Within this document you find a self-contained open specification of the FINESCE WP5 Charging Optimisation System (COS).

Please consult the appropriate pages on the FINESCE website in order to understand the complete context of the related FINESCE trials.
Documentation.ReutilisedTech: As mentioned earlier the COS re-uses the FI-WARE Data Handling GE, FI-WARE DB Anonymiser GE, FI-WARE Identity Management GCP GE , FI-WARE Content Based Security GE , FI-WARE Complex Event Processing GE and FI-WARE Cloud Edge GE.

Terms and Conditions: An instance of the COSs reference implementation runs as a part of the Irish trial and is only accessible via its API. Documentation on the API can be found at https://finesce.tssg.org/documentation/index.html
Contact Person:
Miguel Ponce de Leon
TSSG at Waterford Institute of Technology
miguelpdlREMOVE-NO-SPAM@tssg.org
Overview: The WP5 Stream I team have developed an active demand dispatch system as part of the FINESCE API. This system optimises charging profiles for available Electric Vehicles (EV)s on the grid, by taking input of power generation forecasts from system operators‘ web sites and using request-response message exchange patterns with live EVSE's connected to the grid to create an optimised load scheduler every 15 minutes.
